title: A Look into October 2024 Destruction in EVE Online – Move Ops, Crimson Harvest, and the Alliance Tournament Edition
description: It is time once again to look into the EVE Online Monthly Economic Report. As I suggested last month, part of this will be seeing what the Goonswarm Federation move from Delve to Tenerifis has on destruction.  However, I will save the other economic impacts for another post since I don’t want to get bogged […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: It is time once again to look into the EVE Online Monthly Economic Report. As I suggested last month, part of this will be seeing what the Goonswarm Federation move from Delve to Tenerifis has on d…
text: It is time once again to look into the EVE Online Monthly Economic Report. As I suggested last month, part of this will be seeing what the Goonswarm Federation move from Delve to Tenerifis has on destruction.  However, I will save the other economic impacts for another post since I don’t want to get bogged down or run too long on that in this post. EVE Online nerds harder Here are the usual places to look if you want more details or different coverage of New Eden economic activity for the month. CCP – October 2024 Monthly Economic Report CCP – October 2024 MER Forum Thread Reddit – October 2024 MER Thread TNG – October 2024 Activity In EVE Online TNG – A Look At The October 2024 Active ISK Delta YouTube – October MER Analysis with CSMs Oz and Angry Mustache Overall Summary For openers, with the September MER I wondered if the “summer slump” was over.  With the October MER I think we can absolutely declare that to be the case.  Jester’s chart shows the boost in logins to the game. Average daily players so far in 2024 Numbers are up for sure, though there is a question as to what is driving it.  Jester opined on Reddit that he though it was the GSF move op, which got a lot of us to log in… and quite a few to re-sub alts… in order to get stuff from Delve to Tenerifis.  (We’re going to be cursed if CCP sees this uptick and latches onto the idea… again… than making null sec move constantly is a path to success rather than a way to get us to all quit.) In the October activity post linked above, TNG suggests that the Crimson Harvest event drove this uptick. I lean more towards the move op, in part because I was there personally when we had more than 5K accounts logged in for the first big crossing of the regional gate, and because, historically, there hasn’t been a big uptick that one could solely attribute to Crimson Harvest, which I find to be something of a middling event in New Eden. Oct 2024 – Four year users comparison Yes, we see that uptick in 2023 as well, but that was also the start of the Havoc expansion events, including Zarzakh, so Crimson Harvest was in the mix.  And in 2022 and 2021 October is flat or even down a bit.  So Crimson Harvest doesn’t feel like a big factor in driving users to log into the game. Also, we’re clearly not back up to the peak numbers for the year, which happened when Equinox launched and CCP gave out 7 free days of Omega time and had a login event… though even that peak was still riding somewhat on the boost from Havoc and fell off pretty hard during the summer when Equinox languished, waiting for updates. One item to look for in the November numbers is how much that free time give away spikes the Revenant expansion and whether it can hold through the holidays and into the new year. But what about destruction?  That is the point of this post, right? Well, destruction was up! October saw reported 496,807 hulls, structures, and capsules destroyed, up from the 456,571 reported in September and the 426,589 reported in August.  More things exploded. That gives us an average losses per day number of 16,026, which is a noticeable uptick on the chart I have been keeping. Oct 2024 – Avg Losses per Day – Four Year Comp That makes October 2024 the most explosive October, even if I go back to 2020 when World War Bee was in full swing. On the ISK front, October saw the loss of 44.78 trillion ISK, a serious jump from the 38.73 trillion ISK.  The October number includes losses in the Alliance Tournament, which takes place in Jove space on the main server now, that reportedly added 697 kills worth an estimated total of 1.3 trillion ISK to the month’s total.  That is enough ISK to put it in the top ten of regions for losses. (You can see the biggest loss here.) However, the regional and system losses in the MER don’t reflect that in full (which I will call out later), so once again CCP is doing calculations from different data sets that I cannot reconcile.  I suspect that maybe it is zKillboard pricing vs. CCP pricing, or maybe it is losses including and excluding what dropped in the wreck (90% of those officer mods dropped, but do you get to loot the field after a match?) but couldn’t tell you for sure.  Or maybe they are including the preliminaries that too place previously.  Anyway, there is about half that 1.3 trillion ISK accounted for here. You can however see the AT representing in the losses per day chart for October.  The final rounds were on the 19th, 20th, 26th, and 27th. Oct 2024 – Losses per day Weekends always spike, but Alliance Tournament weekends especially so it seems, with the final day topping the month. Top 20 Most Frequent Losses by Class and Hull By this point in the venture, I post these two charts looking for exceptions in the behavior rather than to remind people that things remain the same. Class  Count  % of Oct Hull  Count  % of Oct Capsule        115,799 23.31% Capsule        114,662 23.08% Shuttle           75,275 15.15% Caldari Shuttle           30,398 6.12% Frigate           59,120 11.90% Ibis           16,626 3.35% Cruiser           38,745 7.80% Gallente Shuttle           16,313 3.28% Destroyer           35,406 7.13% Amarr Shuttle           15,290 3.08% Corvette           30,233 6.09% Minmatar Shuttle           12,199 2.46% Combat Battlecruiser           15,028 3.02% Mobile Tractor Unit           11,335 2.28% Mobile Tractor Unit           11,961 2.41% Venture           10,874 2.19% Hauler           10,738 2.16% Catalyst             9,255 1.86% Heavy Assault Cruiser             8,905 1.79% Heron             7,226 1.45% Interdictor             8,868 1.78% Vexor             7,048 1.42% Interceptor             7,768 1.56% Reaper             6,687 1.35% Assault Frigate             7,672 1.54% Algos             6,120 1.23% Battleship             7,554 1.52% Ishtar             5,447 1.10% Covert Ops             5,225 1.05% Exequror Navy Issue             5,417 1.09% Strategic Cruiser             4,610 0.93% Gnosis             4,576 0.92% Mobile Warp Disruptor             4,565 0.92% Velator             4,480 0.90% Stealth Bomber             4,254 0.86% Thrasher             3,912 0.79% Tactical Destroyer             3,892 0.78% Sabre             3,880 0.78% Mining Barge             3,587 0.72% Mobile Small Warp Disruptor I             3,029 0.61% At a glance, I do wonder why the Gnosis popped up into the top 20 this month, though I suspect it is because it is a cheap battlecruiser hull that is easy to train suicide gank alts into.  That was probably something influenced by Crimson Harvest and the 90% drop rate. Hulls Lost only Once This Month The once per month club, excluding POS towers and modules along with fighter squadrons, is once again fairly short.  Kill mails linked in the table where possible. Hull Count Bestla 1 Covert Mobile Cynosural Beacon 1 Hubris 1 InterBus Shuttle 1 Keepstar 1 ‘Prometheus’ Fortizar 1 Vehement 1 Violator 1 Wyvern 1 Not a lot of interesting stuff on that list.  It is strange, for example, where there isn’t a Wyvern on this list on any given month.  Lancer dreads are rare only in the fact that they don’t get a lot of use. The Bestla is an ATXVIII ship, so rare, but not the first one to blow up.  The Violator was a Pax East 2013 gift, so rare if not exactly formidable.  The InterBus Shuttle came with the boxed version of the game at one point. There is a tale behind the Keepstar and Fortizar losses, which took place in the wormhole system J132601, which was covered in a post over on Reddit. Top 20 Total ISK Lost by Hull Type Hull  Count  Sum of ISK lost % of Oct ISK per Loss Capsule          114,662 3,399.78 billion 7.59% .030 billion Vargur               1,151 2,287.93 billion 5.11% 1.988 billion Golem                  790 1,442.08 billion 3.22% 1.825 billion Loki               1,911 1,403.13 billion 3.13% .734 billion Ishtar               5,447 1,339.69 billion 2.99% .246 billion Kronos                  708 1,229.42 billion 2.75% 1.736 billion Paladin                  669 1,171.08 billion 2.62% 1.750 billion Tengu               1,292 975.70 billion 2.18% .755 billion Praxis               2,748 790.90 billion 1.77% .288 billion Gila               1,971 766.88 billion 1.71% .389 billion Proteus                  805 583.70 billion 1.30% .725 billion Athanor                  355 574.65 billion 1.28% 1.619 billion Rhea                    49 541.55 billion 1.21% 11.052 billion Obelisk                  124 533.62 billion 1.19% 4.303 billion Barghest                  244 499.01 billion 1.11% 2.045 billion Exequror Navy Issue               5,417 488.63 billion 1.09% .090 billion Charon                  127 440.46 billion 0.98% 3.468 billion Occator                  629 433.66 billion 0.97% .689 billion Gnosis               4,576 433.59 billion 0.97% .095 billion Astero               2,530 424.12 billion 0.95% .168 billion There are a lot of haulers on that list, which tempted me initially to credit the move op.  But the move op losses don’t really support that while the losses to suicide ganking during the Crimson Harvest event… again, beloved by gankers for the 90% item drop rate… certainly do. Also, Gnosis on the list here too.  Average loss per hull is just 95 million ISK.  Well worth it to bring down something like a Charon.  Those run about 2 billion ISK for the hull, so when the average loss is 3.5 billion ISK, you know they are dropping goodies to collect. Top 20 Regions by ISK and Hull Losses Here is where those who were hoping to see Goons get abused while trying to move across three regions are going to be disappointed.  But lets see what the chart says before we get into what happened. Region Sum of ISK Lost % of Oct Region  Count  % of Oct Pochven 3.74 trillion 8.34% The Forge        57,751 11.62% Metropolis 2.97 trillion 6.62% Metropolis        31,062 6.25% The Forge 2.71 trillion 6.06% Pochven        26,081 5.25% Delve 2.46 trillion 5.50% Lonetrek        24,220 4.88% The Citadel 2.18 trillion 4.87% Delve        23,876 4.81% Lonetrek 1.33 trillion 2.97% The Citadel        19,272 3.88% Vale of the Silent 1.31 trillion 2.92% Heimatar        18,786 3.78% Sinq Laison 1.27 trillion 2.84% Placid        15,636 3.15% Querious 1.16 trillion 2.60% Catch        15,425 3.10% Catch 1.05 trillion 2.34% Black Rise        13,904 2.80% E-R00024 1.01 trillion 2.25% Querious        13,749 2.77% Genesis .91 trillion 2.04% Sinq Laison        12,794 2.58% Fountain .84 trillion 1.89% Vale of the Silent        12,334 2.48% Omist .73 trillion 1.64% Essence        11,054 2.23% Perrigen Falls .72 trillion 1.61% Genesis           9,996 2.01% Placid .68 trillion 1.53% Perrigen Falls           8,439 1.70% Devoid .65 trillion 1.45% Fountain           8,384 1.69% UUA-F4 .61 trillion 1.36% The Bleak Lands           7,502 1.51% Black Rise .60 trillion 1.34% Omist           6,790 1.37% Tenerifis .59 trillion 1.32% Tenerifis           5,755 1.16% On the one hand, Delve, Querious, Catch, and Tenerifis, the regions where the move ops took place, all made the top 20 list… Tenerifis did not last month… and all of them saw some increase in losses, Delve being the most pronounced, going from 1.41 trillion ISK in September to 2.46 trillion ISK in October, the upswing was not in proportion to the amount of ships and players in motion through those regions over the course of the month. Basically, Fraternity and PanFam did not put in a lot of effort when it came to messing with move ops.  Sure, there were small groups out there with gate camps and opportunistic kills, including the old “invite to fleet” trick in 1DQ1-A, which worked more often than it should have. But if we had advance knowledge of the time and place of a gate jump involving super capitals, it would not have been the smooth operation we saw on October 18th when we had over 50K jumps between 49-U6U and 4-07MU. Here they come! There was another video of the op in last week’s community beat, and the one thing you don’t see if opposition to thousands of ships going back and forth. And you may fairly ask what I expected if we had 5K pilots logged on. At a minimum, if it were me, I would have had 50 logged out interdictors in each system, ready to log in when it was there turn, drop a bubble and cloak, and keep it up until they were blown up and then have the next one log in, on both sides of the gate. We call this waterboarding, and it not only disrupts the tempo of the operation, it freaks out the capital pilots flying very expensive hulls packed with all their stuff.  People will get frustrated and log out. Rather than being a constant irritation and disruption, it happened exactly once in 4-07MU when a clever interdictor dropped a drag bubble behind the Keepstar.  And that was it.  The move op went on and on with negligible resistance.  Unless an Imperium pilot decided to go gate all the way to ULAX on their own, they were safe. And that is just my baseline idea.  I am sure the Imperium could come up with a dozen more things to make a hostile move op go wrong.  But Frat and PanFam weren’t interested, which helped us out. The other regions worth bringing up are Pochven, which again tops the list.  I don’t even know what goes on in Pochven, but there they are again. Then there is The Forge, where suicide ganking in and around Jita added a trillion ISK to the losses in September. Following on, there is E-R00024, the wormhole region where that Keepstar and faction Fortizar were lost, breaking the trillion ISK mark. And, finally, there is UUA-F4, which is where the Alliance Tournament took place, which rang in with 610 billion ISK in losses, about half of the 1.3 trillion ISK claimed were AT losses. Top 20 Systems by ISK and Hull Losses Down at the system level we can see where things were happening. System Region Sum of ISK lost % of Oct System Region  Count  % of Oct Jita The Forge 1317.01 billion 2.94% Uitra The Forge        38,610 7.77% Uedama The Citadel 983.71 billion 2.20% Jita The Forge        10,877 2.19% 1DQ1-A Delve 828.91 billion 1.85% Ahbazon Genesis           7,665 1.54% TI0-AX UUA-F4 535.72 billion 1.20% Uedama The Citadel           7,597 1.53% Gheth Devoid 483.03 billion 1.08% Malukker Heimatar           6,405 1.29% Ahbazon Genesis 464.40 billion 1.04% Akiainavas Lonetrek           5,886 1.18% J132601 E-R00024 464.04 billion 1.04% Jouvulen Lonetrek           4,813 0.97% Sakenta Pochven 360.48 billion 0.80% Korama Lonetrek           4,333 0.87% Kaunokka Pochven 349.74 billion 0.78% Vlillirier Placid           4,329 0.87% Sivala The Citadel 331.81 billion 0.74% 1DQ1-A Delve           4,214 0.85% Aufay Sinq Laison 288.46 billion 0.64% Tama The Citadel           3,695 0.74% Tunudan Pochven 270.74 billion 0.60% Kinakka Black Rise           3,590 0.72% Aset Metropolis 265.24 billion 0.59% Heydieles Essence           3,143 0.63% Isanamo Lonetrek 245.74 billion 0.55% J132601 E-R00024           3,046 0.61% Frerstorn Metropolis 242.40 billion 0.54% Rancer Sinq Laison           3,018 0.61% 49-U6U Querious 232.89 billion 0.52% Tunudan Pochven           2,972 0.60% Nalvula Pochven 227.41 billion 0.51% Amamake Heimatar           2,969 0.60% G-B3PR Omist 213.35 billion 0.48% Aset Metropolis           2,944 0.59% Konola Pochven 210.47 billion 0.47% HY-RWO Catch           2,668 0.54% Rancer Sinq Laison 179.72 billion 0.40% Trossere Sinq Laison           2,464 0.50% On the ISK side of the chart, Jita and Uedama are the favored suicide ganking locations, with both seeing more than double the usual losses due to the Crimson Harvest 90% drop. 1DQ1-A is in third due to small group efforts to warp off and kill oblivious Imperium pilots… quite a successful operation.  We lost two titans in one day, which make up more than half of the total losses.  Imagine if Frat and PanFam had really tried to disrupt things? TI0-AX is where the Alliance Tournament took place, while J132601 is the wormhole where the Keepstar and faction Fortizar were destroyed.  Must have been a couple of nice loot pinatas. On the hull count side… well, there is Uitra again, the birth place of suicide gank clones.  Or that is my theory.  Utria gets its own section.  Jita is in second place on count, as one might expect. Interesting to me is that there is really only one system on the move op route to UALX in the top 20 for count, HY-RWO.  Gate camps popped up there a lot and they got a lot of small stuff. The Obligatory Count from Uitra Here we are again, staring at Uitra and trying to figure out what is going on.  Here are the losses for the system for October. Hull  Count  Sum of ISK lost Caldari Shuttle        16,261 399.36 million Ibis           8,856 797.56 million Minmatar Shuttle           4,657 83.13 million Gallente Shuttle           4,506 69.27 million Amarr Shuttle           3,056 84.12 million Velator              750 69.09 million Capsule              163 .07 million Badger              157 133.82 million Merlin                81 13.63 million Reaper                34 3.06 million Impairor                33 3.07 million Venture                15 4.65 million Gnosis                11 585.44 million Bantam                  8 .96 million Griffin                  6 2.27 million Heron                  6 6.15 million Condor                  3 6.52 million Cormorant                  2 2.70 million Astero                  1 245.71 million Caracal                  1 10.59 million Praxis                  1 177.51 million Slasher                  1 1.31 million Sunesis                  1 5.82 million On the shuttle front, that is 28,480 in October, or roughly 38% of all shuttles lost in the game in October, all in a 0.9 security system in Caldari high sec.  That is up from last month. The shuttle tally so far in 2024: October – 28,480 September – 20,378 August – 20,298 July – 35,739 June – 39,863 May – 37,008 April – 27,446 March – 22,149 February – 26,778 January – 20,674 How does that compare to other systems?  Are there other shuttle hot spots?  Here are all the systems were about a thousand or more shuttles were lost. Hull  Count  Sum of ISK Lost System Region Shuttle        28,480 635.89 million Uitra The Forge Shuttle           5,331 105.88 million Akiainavas Lonetrek Shuttle           4,307 97.59 million Korama Lonetrek Shuttle           3,978 88.44 million Jouvulen Lonetrek Shuttle           2,450 49.26 million Trossere Sinq Laison Shuttle           2,169 5,268.55 million Jita The Forge Shuttle           1,785 46.42 million Malukker Heimatar Shuttle           1,627 30.65 million Embod Metropolis Shuttle           1,585 37.82 million Deepari Domain Shuttle           1,383 34.40 million J102055 D-R00021 Shuttle           1,285 21.22 million Couster Essence Shuttle           1,048 2,287.86 million Ahbazon Genesis Shuttle              922 205.80 million J132601 E-R00024 Akiainavas is another starter system, and most of those are high sec.  I am kind of curios as to what use a shuttle is in wormhole space, but somebody can always scout you a hole I suppose. Jita and Ahbazon are where people hauling expensive stuff in shuttles get caught.  But Uitra is the shuttle graveyard. As with last month, I kept an alt in there.  He undocks when the AIR daily requires scanning 5 signatures, easy to do in a training system, and I see the usual stuff there.  When I undock there are always cargo containers, abandoned ships, and like on the littering the place. The messy undock The overview shows me lots of things, including characters with numerically sequenced names. Must be a coincidence And they generally have just one day in game, during which they all joined the same corp. Birds of a feather and all that One day I saw a pair of Gnosis on the undock applying ewar to each other, presumably to hit some AIR goal that would grant them some more skill points. Just sitting on the undock On character was a month old, the other was the usual one day old, which is what made me think that the spike in Gnosis kills I mentioned way up above was related to suicide ganking. And so it goes.  Once again, I cannot prove in any tangible way that this is all a suicide ganker alt creation factory in progress, but I also cannot come up with a better explanation that fits the few facts I have. Next month the question will be whether or not tomorrow’s Revenant expansion sets CCP up for a strong end of year population.
html:
It is time once again to look into the EVE Online Monthly Economic Report.

As I suggested last month, part of this will be seeing what the Goonswarm Federation move from Delve to Tenerifis has on destruction.  However, I will save the other economic impacts for another post since I don’t want to get bogged down or run too long on that in this post.

EVE Online nerds harder

Here are the usual places to look if you want more details or different coverage of New Eden economic activity for the month.

  • CCP – October 2024 Monthly Economic Report
  • CCP – October 2024 MER Forum Thread
  • Reddit – October 2024 MER Thread
  • TNG – October 2024 Activity In EVE Online
  • TNG – A Look At The October 2024 Active ISK Delta
  • YouTube – October MER Analysis with CSMs Oz and Angry Mustache

Overall Summary

For openers, with the September MER I wondered if the “summer slump” was over.  With the October MER I think we can absolutely declare that to be the case.  Jester’s chart shows the boost in logins to the game.

Average daily players so far in 2024

Numbers are up for sure, though there is a question as to what is driving it.  Jester opined on Reddit that he though it was the GSF move op, which got a lot of us to log in… and quite a few to re-sub alts… in order to get stuff from Delve to Tenerifis.  (We’re going to be cursed if CCP sees this uptick and latches onto the idea… again… than making null sec move constantly is a path to success rather than a way to get us to all quit.)

In the October activity post linked above, TNG suggests that the Crimson Harvest event drove this uptick.

I lean more towards the move op, in part because I was there personally when we had more than 5K accounts logged in for the first big crossing of the regional gate, and because, historically, there hasn’t been a big uptick that one could solely attribute to Crimson Harvest, which I find to be something of a middling event in New Eden.

Oct 2024 – Four year users comparison

Yes, we see that uptick in 2023 as well, but that was also the start of the Havoc expansion events, including Zarzakh, so Crimson Harvest was in the mix.  And in 2022 and 2021 October is flat or even down a bit.  So Crimson Harvest doesn’t feel like a big factor in driving users to log into the game.

Also, we’re clearly not back up to the peak numbers for the year, which happened when Equinox launched and CCP gave out 7 free days of Omega time and had a login event… though even that peak was still riding somewhat on the boost from Havoc and fell off pretty hard during the summer when Equinox languished, waiting for updates.

One item to look for in the November numbers is how much that free time give away spikes the Revenant expansion and whether it can hold through the holidays and into the new year.

But what about destruction?  That is the point of this post, right?

Well, destruction was up!

October saw reported 496,807 hulls, structures, and capsules destroyed, up from the 456,571 reported in September and the 426,589 reported in August.  More things exploded.

That gives us an average losses per day number of 16,026, which is a noticeable uptick on the chart I have been keeping.

Oct 2024 – Avg Losses per Day – Four Year Comp

That makes October 2024 the most explosive October, even if I go back to 2020 when World War Bee was in full swing.

On the ISK front, October saw the loss of 44.78 trillion ISK, a serious jump from the 38.73 trillion ISK.  The October number includes losses in the Alliance Tournament, which takes place in Jove space on the main server now, that reportedly added 697 kills worth an estimated total of 1.3 trillion ISK to the month’s total.  That is enough ISK to put it in the top ten of regions for losses. (You can see the biggest loss here.)

However, the regional and system losses in the MER don’t reflect that in full (which I will call out later), so once again CCP is doing calculations from different data sets that I cannot reconcile.  I suspect that maybe it is zKillboard pricing vs. CCP pricing, or maybe it is losses including and excluding what dropped in the wreck (90% of those officer mods dropped, but do you get to loot the field after a match?) but couldn’t tell you for sure.  Or maybe they are including the preliminaries that too place previously.  Anyway, there is about half that 1.3 trillion ISK accounted for here.

You can however see the AT representing in the losses per day chart for October.  The final rounds were on the 19th, 20th, 26th, and 27th.

Oct 2024 – Losses per day

Weekends always spike, but Alliance Tournament weekends especially so it seems, with the final day topping the month.

Top 20 Most Frequent Losses by Class and Hull

By this point in the venture, I post these two charts looking for exceptions in the behavior rather than to remind people that things remain the same.

Class  Count  % of Oct Hull  Count  % of Oct
Capsule        115,799 23.31% Capsule        114,662 23.08%
Shuttle           75,275 15.15% Caldari Shuttle           30,398 6.12%
Frigate           59,120 11.90% Ibis           16,626 3.35%
Cruiser           38,745 7.80% Gallente Shuttle           16,313 3.28%
Destroyer           35,406 7.13% Amarr Shuttle           15,290 3.08%
Corvette           30,233 6.09% Minmatar Shuttle           12,199 2.46%
Combat Battlecruiser           15,028 3.02% Mobile Tractor Unit           11,335 2.28%
Mobile Tractor Unit           11,961 2.41% Venture           10,874 2.19%
Hauler           10,738 2.16% Catalyst             9,255 1.86%
Heavy Assault Cruiser             8,905 1.79% Heron             7,226 1.45%
Interdictor             8,868 1.78% Vexor             7,048 1.42%
Interceptor             7,768 1.56% Reaper             6,687 1.35%
Assault Frigate             7,672 1.54% Algos             6,120 1.23%
Battleship             7,554 1.52% Ishtar             5,447 1.10%
Covert Ops             5,225 1.05% Exequror Navy Issue             5,417 1.09%
Strategic Cruiser             4,610 0.93% Gnosis             4,576 0.92%
Mobile Warp Disruptor             4,565 0.92% Velator             4,480 0.90%
Stealth Bomber             4,254 0.86% Thrasher             3,912 0.79%
Tactical Destroyer             3,892 0.78% Sabre             3,880 0.78%
Mining Barge             3,587 0.72% Mobile Small Warp Disruptor I             3,029 0.61%

At a glance, I do wonder why the Gnosis popped up into the top 20 this month, though I suspect it is because it is a cheap battlecruiser hull that is easy to train suicide gank alts into.  That was probably something influenced by Crimson Harvest and the 90% drop rate.

Hulls Lost only Once This Month

The once per month club, excluding POS towers and modules along with fighter squadrons, is once again fairly short.  Kill mails linked in the table where possible.

Hull Count
Bestla 1
Covert Mobile Cynosural Beacon 1
Hubris 1
InterBus Shuttle 1
Keepstar 1
‘Prometheus’ Fortizar 1
Vehement 1
Violator 1
Wyvern 1

Not a lot of interesting stuff on that list.  It is strange, for example, where there isn’t a Wyvern on this list on any given month.  Lancer dreads are rare only in the fact that they don’t get a lot of use.

The Bestla is an ATXVIII ship, so rare, but not the first one to blow up.  The Violator was a Pax East 2013 gift, so rare if not exactly formidable.  The InterBus Shuttle came with the boxed version of the game at one point.

There is a tale behind the Keepstar and Fortizar losses, which took place in the wormhole system J132601, which was covered in a post over on Reddit.

There are a lot of haulers on that list, which tempted me initially to credit the move op.  But the move op losses don’t really support that while the losses to suicide ganking during the Crimson Harvest event… again, beloved by gankers for the 90% item drop rate… certainly do.

Also, Gnosis on the list here too.  Average loss per hull is just 95 million ISK.  Well worth it to bring down something like a Charon.  Those run about 2 billion ISK for the hull, so when the average loss is 3.5 billion ISK, you know they are dropping goodies to collect.

Top 20 Regions by ISK and Hull Losses

Here is where those who were hoping to see Goons get abused while trying to move across three regions are going to be disappointed.  But lets see what the chart says before we get into what happened.

On the one hand, Delve, Querious, Catch, and Tenerifis, the regions where the move ops took place, all made the top 20 list… Tenerifis did not last month… and all of them saw some increase in losses, Delve being the most pronounced, going from 1.41 trillion ISK in September to 2.46 trillion ISK in October, the upswing was not in proportion to the amount of ships and players in motion through those regions over the course of the month.

Basically, Fraternity and PanFam did not put in a lot of effort when it came to messing with move ops.  Sure, there were small groups out there with gate camps and opportunistic kills, including the old “invite to fleet” trick in 1DQ1-A, which worked more often than it should have.

But if we had advance knowledge of the time and place of a gate jump involving super capitals, it would not have been the smooth operation we saw on October 18th when we had over 50K jumps between 49-U6U and 4-07MU.

Here they come!

There was another video of the op in last week’s community beat, and the one thing you don’t see if opposition to thousands of ships going back and forth.

And you may fairly ask what I expected if we had 5K pilots logged on.

At a minimum, if it were me, I would have had 50 logged out interdictors in each system, ready to log in when it was there turn, drop a bubble and cloak, and keep it up until they were blown up and then have the next one log in, on both sides of the gate.

We call this waterboarding, and it not only disrupts the tempo of the operation, it freaks out the capital pilots flying very expensive hulls packed with all their stuff.  People will get frustrated and log out.

Rather than being a constant irritation and disruption, it happened exactly once in 4-07MU when a clever interdictor dropped a drag bubble behind the Keepstar.  And that was it.  The move op went on and on with negligible resistance.  Unless an Imperium pilot decided to go gate all the way to ULAX on their own, they were safe.

And that is just my baseline idea.  I am sure the Imperium could come up with a dozen more things to make a hostile move op go wrong.  But Frat and PanFam weren’t interested, which helped us out.

The other regions worth bringing up are Pochven, which again tops the list.  I don’t even know what goes on in Pochven, but there they are again.

Then there is The Forge, where suicide ganking in and around Jita added a trillion ISK to the losses in September.

Following on, there is E-R00024, the wormhole region where that Keepstar and faction Fortizar were lost, breaking the trillion ISK mark.

And, finally, there is UUA-F4, which is where the Alliance Tournament took place, which rang in with 610 billion ISK in losses, about half of the 1.3 trillion ISK claimed were AT losses.

On the ISK side of the chart, Jita and Uedama are the favored suicide ganking locations, with both seeing more than double the usual losses due to the Crimson Harvest 90% drop.

1DQ1-A is in third due to small group efforts to warp off and kill oblivious Imperium pilots… quite a successful operation.  We lost two titans in one day, which make up more than half of the total losses.  Imagine if Frat and PanFam had really tried to disrupt things?

TI0-AX is where the Alliance Tournament took place, while J132601 is the wormhole where the Keepstar and faction Fortizar were destroyed.  Must have been a couple of nice loot pinatas.

On the hull count side… well, there is Uitra again, the birth place of suicide gank clones.  Or that is my theory.  Utria gets its own section.  Jita is in second place on count, as one might expect.

Interesting to me is that there is really only one system on the move op route to UALX in the top 20 for count, HY-RWO.  Gate camps popped up there a lot and they got a lot of small stuff.

On the shuttle front, that is 28,480 in October, or roughly 38% of all shuttles lost in the game in October, all in a 0.9 security system in Caldari high sec.  That is up from last month.

The shuttle tally so far in 2024:

  • October – 28,480
  • September – 20,378
  • August – 20,298
  • July – 35,739
  • June – 39,863
  • May – 37,008
  • April – 27,446
  • March – 22,149
  • February – 26,778
  • January – 20,674

Akiainavas is another starter system, and most of those are high sec.  I am kind of curios as to what use a shuttle is in wormhole space, but somebody can always scout you a hole I suppose.

Jita and Ahbazon are where people hauling expensive stuff in shuttles get caught.  But Uitra is the shuttle graveyard.

As with last month, I kept an alt in there.  He undocks when the AIR daily requires scanning 5 signatures, easy to do in a training system, and I see the usual stuff there.  When I undock there are always cargo containers, abandoned ships, and like on the littering the place.

The messy undock

The overview shows me lots of things, including characters with numerically sequenced names.

Must be a coincidence

And they generally have just one day in game, during which they all joined the same corp.

Birds of a feather and all that

One day I saw a pair of Gnosis on the undock applying ewar to each other, presumably to hit some AIR goal that would grant them some more skill points.

Just sitting on the undock

On character was a month old, the other was the usual one day old, which is what made me think that the spike in Gnosis kills I mentioned way up above was related to suicide ganking.

And so it goes.  Once again, I cannot prove in any tangible way that this is all a suicide ganker alt creation factory in progress, but I also cannot come up with a better explanation that fits the few facts I have.

Next month the question will be whether or not tomorrow’s Revenant expansion sets CCP up for a strong end of year population.
